elements.text: because you want to enforce the name and you want to export multiple things from the same file.

text: when you destructure you are forced to destructure based on the name of the key that you want. therefore you have an idea (provided that the key names are good) of what you are actually importing there.

text:
From a hacker-attacking point of view:

If somebody is logging in with a "wrong" username, let´s say "brend" instead of "bernd",
is it okay to let the user know "hey, we don´t have that username" or is this already bad?

elements.text:
From a hacker-attacking point of view:

If somebody is logging in with a "wrong" username, let´s say "brend" instead of "bernd",
is it okay to let the user know "hey, we don´t have that username" or is this already bad?

text: it's already bad.

elements.text: it's already bad.

text: but you have to tell a user that a username is already taken if they try to sign up so there's no way around it really.

elements.text: but you have to tell a user that a username is already taken if they try to sign up so there's no way around it really.

text:
But then I need the exact same error-message for
-wrong username and
-correct username, wrong password

elements.text:
But then I need the exact same error-message for
-wrong username and
-correct username, wrong password

text: Yes, I thought about that...

elements.text: Yes, I thought about that...

text: I mean during sign up.

elements.text: I mean during sign up.

text: but still the correlation that you can get out of the message on the login that we built today is worse than having an error message that doesn't tell you.

elements.text: but still the correlation that you can get out of the message on the login that we built today is worse than having an error message that doesn't tell you.

text: i.e. a generic error message is harder for a hacker to exploit, because they can't brute force a username/password combination, since they can't try 1.000 passwords for a username they don't know exists easily.

elements.text: i.e. a generic error message is harder for a hacker to exploit, because they can't brute force a username/password combination, since they can't try 1.000 passwords for a username they don't know exists easily.

text: but then this whole argument is void once you have a signup form that gives you that information haha

elements.text: but then this whole argument is void once you have a signup form that gives you that information haha

text: Yes

elements.text: Yes

text: :thumbsup:
but in the end, probably the part that happens more often is that users just give hackers their passwords for free rather than brute force targeted attacks.

elements.text: but in the end, probably the part that happens more often is that users just give hackers their passwords for free rather than brute force targeted attacks.

text: the latter is more used against pwning a single account of a key figure somewhere usually.

elements.text: the latter is more used against pwning a single account of a key figure somewhere usually.

text: for free => targeted phishing attempts

elements.text: for free => targeted phishing attempts
